column4: where can I request to add new software in ubuntu repositories?
chances are it will fall on deaf ears unless you package it yourself...
you mean I've to package it by myself in launchpad.net
I think you can submit a bug as a feature request. I am not sure. But the best way to get something included is to make a package and then submit it.

damn, there is a huge gap in Winrar alternative in ubuntu I discuss it with KDE community and I found that best thing is to request to add q7z in ubutnu repository (q7z exists in openSuSE repository)... see kde discussion http://tinyurl.com/3cl3cn4
what do you need winrar for?
usually in winrar the user can set compression ratio where in Ark it can't be so the user forced to use peazip or q7z where both of them not exist in ubuntu repositories
are you try to make a rar file? why does it matter if you can set a compression ratio?
also, what program do you recommend ubuntu get?
I want to create 7z file with hightest compression (9), this can done from CLI where it can't in GUI
interesting. what program do you want to install?
http://kde-apps.org/content/show.php?content=45453
see this discussion too http://tinyurl.com/3cl3cn4
I guess you should file a bug. I think when you file a bug you can mark it as an enhancement. However, I think it is unlikely someone will take it :-\
or, you can file a bug with ark upstream...
that is more likely to be handled ;-)
yes, thanks for suggestion
you can also make your own then go into the ubuntu dev channel and ask for someone to review/submit it. Sort of a mentorship thing.
they tend to like to do that ;-)
or you just compile by source and not try... but it helps the community when you fix it for everyone :-D
unfortunately I don't have any experience in building deb packages.... I read tons of resource but I found them very compicated
it is far too complicated... arch packages are so much easier :-P
I have made rpms, debs, and arch linux packages. But I have too many projects on my plate to help with this :-\
Dulak is correct. They are just compressed tar files (I don't believe they use gz for compression anymore)
